elements.content: Eight different coordination polymers (CPs) of Co2+ and Zn2+ ions with rigid polycarboxylate ligands (fumaric acid (fum) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephalic acid (dhbdc)) have been synthesized using the same solvents, stoichiometry, and counterion but two different synthetic methods: liquid–liquid diffusion method–method A and pH control method–method B. The synthesis using method A resulted in four novel CPs: trans-Co­(dmso)2­(H2O)2­(fum)] n (1), [trans-Zn­(dmso)2­(H2O)2­(fum)] n (2), trans-Co­(dmso)2­(H2O)2­(dhbdc)] n (3), and [trans-Zn­(dmso)2­(H2O)2­(dhbdc)] n (4). Synthesis using method B resulted in one new ([Zn­(fum)­(OH)2] (6)) and three previously described CPs ([Co3(H2O)4­(OH)2­(fum)2]­·2H2O (5), [Co2(dobdc)] (7), and [Zn2(dobdc)] (8), where dobdc = 2,5-dioxyterephtalic acid). The new CPs (1–4) were also structurally investigated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques, which showed that all of them form one-dimensional (1D) CPs with linear chain structure: it was evidenced that (1) and (3) are isomorphus crystals of (2) and (4), respectively. The crystal structures of 1–4 were compared with similar 1D, two- and three-dimensional (2D and 3D) CPs reported in the literature. Intra- and interchain H-bond networks and coordination (fum, dhbdc, DMSO, water) as well as linkage (fum and dhbdc) isomerism guide the chain configuration (linear or zigzag). It was also demonstrated that the new series of 1D CPs synthesized here (1–4) can work as precursors for CP with higher dimensionality. Our studies showed that the synthetic method plays a crucial role in the crystal growth of coordination polymers.

elements.content: Coordination polymers of Co2+ and Zn2+ ions with rigid polycarboxylate ligands (fumaric acid and 2,5-dihydroxyterephalic acid) have been synthesized using the same solvents, stoichiometry, and counterion but two different synthetic methods: the liquid−liquid diffusion method and pH control method. Isomorphism and multiple cis−trans isomerism are discussed.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) are supramolecular assemblies of metal ions (or metal clusters) and organic ligands linked through coordination bonds, and characterization of infinite one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) networks has been an area of rapid growth.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) are supramolecular assemblies of metal ions (or metal clusters) and organic ligands linked through coordination bonds, and characterization of infinite one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) networks has been an area of rapid growth.

elements.content: Since the bulk properties of solids are highly dependent on their structure, chemists must focus their attention on the controllable synthesis of specific functional materials. The controllable preparation of crystalline CPs is still a challenge because many factors in the synthesis, such as solvent, metal ion, pH, as well as the synthetic method, have a crucial influence on the nucleation and crystallization process. The solvent used in the synthesis of CPs is a crucial parameter whose influence is widely studied, due to its capability of governing the kinetics and thermodynamics of the reaction during the coordination process. Moreover, the method of synthesis used to obtain CPs can lead to the formation of different products (including different molecular formula, structure, and dimensionality) even when starting from the same reactants (metal, ligand, and solvent) and may also have a strong impact on reaction time, yield, and particle size. An example of the impact of the synthetic route in the CP formation can be observed in the synthesis of Zn­(II) CPs with bpy (bipyridine) and H2nip (5-nitroisophthalic acid) ligands: under solvothermal conditions the synthesis provides a 1D ribbon chain at 140 °C and a 2D layer at 180 °C, while under a diffusion route, a different 2D layer is obtained.

Moreover, the method of synthesis used to obtain CPs can lead to the formation of different products (including different molecular formula, structure, and dimensionality) even when starting from the same reactants (metal, ligand, and solvent) and may also have a strong impact on reaction time, yield, and particle size. An example of the impact of the synthetic route in the CP formation can be observed in the synthesis of Zn(II) CPs with bpy (bipyridine) and H2nip (5-nitroisophthalic acid) ligands: under solvothermal conditions the synthesis provides a 1D ribbon chain at 140 °C and a 2D layer at 180 °C, while under a diffusion route, a different 2D layer is obtained.

elements.content: In the present contribution, we attempted to investigate the different roles of the synthetic method in the construction of the CPs. The use of two different routes led to the formation of four new compounds involving the metal ions Co2+ and Zn2+, and the ligands fumaric (fum) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephtalic (dhbdc) acids, and three compounds previously reported in the literature. Here, we compile the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal properties of these compounds, discussing isomorphism, multiple cis–trans isomerism, and other structural relationships.

The use of two different routes led to the formation of four new compounds involving the metal ions Co2+ and Zn2+, and the ligands fumaric (fum) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephtalic (dhbdc) acids, and three compounds previously reported in the literature. Here, we compile the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal properties of these compounds, discussing isomorphism, multiple cis-trans isomerism, and other structural relationships.

elements.content: All reagents and chemicals were purchased commercially and used as received. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on Empyrean Panalytical diffractometer using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the angular range of 2θ = 5–40°. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a SDT Q600 (TA Instruments) unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under a synthetic air atmosphere. Elemental analyses (EA) for C, H, and N were performed using a LECO TruSpec-CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectroscopy analyses were performed on Thermo Scientific spectrophotometer FT-IR IS50, with a 4 cm–1 resolution in the range of 4000 to 400 cm−1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and chemicals were purchased commercially and used as received. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on Empyrean Panalytical diffractometer using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the angular range of 2θ = 5-40°. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a SDT Q600 (TA Instruments) unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under a synthetic air atmosphere. Elemental analyses (EA) for C, H, and N were performed using a LECO TruSpec-CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectroscopy analyses were performed on Thermo Scientific spectrophotometer FT-IR IS50, with a 4 cm-1 resolution in the range of 4000 to 400 cm-1.

elements.content: A DMSO solution of ligand (0.20 mmol, 2 mL) placed at the bottom of a glass tube (13 × 100 mm) was covered with a DMSO/water mixture (3:1 v/v, 4 mL), over which an aqueous solution of cobalt or zinc nitrate (0.20 mmol, 2 mL) was layered.
elements.clean_text:
Synthetic Procedures

Liquid-Liquid Diffusion - Method A

A DMSO solution of ligand (0.20 mmol, 2 mL) placed at the bottom of a glass tube (13 × 100 mm) was covered with a DMSO/water mixture (3:1 v/v, 4 mL), over which an aqueous solution of cobalt or zinc nitrate (0.20 mmol, 2 mL) was layered.

elements.content: An aqueous solution of metal salt (2.00 mmol, 5 mL) was added to a DMSO solution of ligand (1.00 mmol, 15 mL). This mixture was adjusted to pH ≈ 7 with an aqueous solution of NaOH (1.00 mol L–1) and stirred for 5 h at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
pH Control Method - Method B

An aqueous solution of metal salt (2.00 mmol, 5 mL) was added to a DMSO solution of ligand (1.00 mmol, 15 mL). This mixture was adjusted to pH ~ 7 with an aqueous solution of NaOH (1.00 mol L-1) and stirred for 5 h at room temperature.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data collections were performed on an Oxford-Diffraction GEMINI diffractometer using Graphite-Enhance Source Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data integration and scaling of the reflections and analytical absorption corrections were carried out with the programs of the Crysalis suite. Final unit cell parameters were based on the fitting of all reflection positions. The structures were solved using direct methods using the Sir-92 program. For each compound, the positions of the carbon, oxygen, sulfur, and metal atoms of the molecules were unambiguously assigned on consecutive difference Fourier maps. Refinements were performed with SHELXL-2013 based on F2 through a full-matrix least-squares routine. All atoms were refined with anisotropic atomic displacement parameters, except for hydrogen. The latter were located in difference maps and included as fixed contributions according to the riding model. For organic moieties C–H = 0.97 Å and U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C) for aromatic carbon atoms. Methyl groups C–H = 0.97 Å and U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement are shown in . CCDC 1439600, 1439601, 1439602, 1439603 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/getstructures.

Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

X-ray diffraction data collections were performed on an Oxford-Diffraction GEMINI diffractometer using Graphite-Enhance Source Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data integration and scaling of the reflections and analytical absorption corrections were carried out with the programs of the Crysalis suite. Final unit cell parameters were based on the fitting of all reflection positions. The structures were solved using direct methods using the Sir-92 program. For each compound, the positions of the carbon, oxygen, sulfur, and metal atoms of the molecules were unambiguously assigned on consecutive difference Fourier maps. Refinements were performed with SHELXL-2013  based on F2 through a full-matrix least-squares routine. All atoms were refined with anisotropic atomic displacement parameters, except for hydrogen. The latter were located in difference maps and included as fixed contributions according to the riding model. For organic moieties C-H = 0.97 Å and U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C) for aromatic carbon atoms. Methyl groups C-H = 0.97 Å and U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement are shown in . CCDC 1439600, 1439601, 1439602, 1439603 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/getstructures.

In order to investigate the impact of synthetic method upon the CP formation, two different strategies were used: liquid–liquid diffusion (method A) and pH control method (method B).

The reaction of Co2+ and Zn2+ with fum and dhbdc under diffusion conditions (method A) resulted in the products (1–4), in which two ligands (fum or dhbdc), two DMSO, and two water molecules coordinate the metal cations (Co2+ or Zn2+). Interestingly, the crystals of the coordination polymers (1) and (3) are isomorphous to (2) and (4), respectively (). They present very similar cell dimensions and comparable fractional atomic coordinates differing only in the nature of a cation: Co2+ for (1) and (3), and Zn2+ for (2) and (4) ( and ). This structural feature will be discussed later.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

In order to investigate the impact of synthetic method upon the CP formation, two different strategies were used: liquid-liquid diffusion (method A) and pH control method (method B).

The reaction of Co2+ and Zn2+ with fum and dhbdc under diffusion conditions (method A) resulted in the products (1-4), in which two ligands (fum or dhbdc), two DMSO, and two water molecules coordinate the metal cations (Co2+ or Zn2+). Interestingly, the crystals of the coordination polymers (1) and (3) are isomorphous to (2) and (4), respectively (). They present very similar cell dimensions and comparable fractional atomic coordinates differing only in the nature of a cation: Co2+ for (1) and (3), and Zn2+ for (2) and (4) ( and ). This structural feature will be discussed later.

The H atoms are represented as spheres with arbitrary radii, and the ellipsoids of the non-H atoms are drawn at the 50% probability level. Symmetry codes in (a): i–x, −y, −z; ii x, y+1, z; iii x, y–1, z; −x, −y–1, −z. Symmetry codes in (b): i–x+1, −y+1, −z+1; ii x–1, y+1, z; iii–x+2, −y, −z+1.

elements.content: The reaction of Co2+ with fum by method B at room temperature led to the formation of the 3D CP (5), that was previously reported by Zheng et al., using Co­(OH)2–2x ­(CO3) x ­·yH2O and fum (1:1) in CH3OH/water (3:1 v/v)). On the other hand, its Zn2+ analogue is a new compound (6), which unfortunately did not form single crystals suitable for structural elucidation. The reaction of Co2+ and Zn2+ with dhbdc by the same method led to the formation of the product (7) and (8) (M-MOF-74), 3D isomorphic complexes previously reported by Dietzel et al. obtained under solvothermal conditions using Zn­(NO3)2­·4H2O and dhbdc (2:1 stoichiometry). It is important to emphasize that in these complexes, the polar aprotic solvent (DMSO) does not coordinate the cations or solvate the whole complex. The structural identifications mentioned above are supported by search/match PXRD analysis (Figure S1, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The reaction of Co2+ with fum by method B at room temperature led to the formation of the 3D CP (5), that was previously reported by Zheng et al., using Co(OH)2-2x (CO3) x ⋅yH2O and fum (1:1) in CH3OH/water (3:1 v/v)). On the other hand, its Zn2+ analogue is a new compound (6), which unfortunately did not form single crystals suitable for structural elucidation. The reaction of Co2+ and Zn2+ with dhbdc by the same method led to the formation of the product (7) and (8) (M-MOF-74), 3D isomorphic complexes previously reported by Dietzel et al. obtained under solvothermal conditions using Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O and dhbdc (2:1 stoichiometry). It is important to emphasize that in these complexes, the polar aprotic solvent (DMSO) does not coordinate the cations or solvate the whole complex. The structural identifications mentioned above are supported by search/match PXRD analysis (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

elements.content: A prerequisite for coordination polymers formation is the complexation of metal units by the organic ligand, which is accompanied by deprotonation of the ligand acid precursor. Thermodynamic factors affecting this step include the acid–base equilibrium between reagents, release of solvent upon complexation, and product crystallization, which acts to drive the reaction forward. The water exchange in the metal coordination sphere, which leads to the complexes formation, is also governed by thermodynamic and kinetic (rate of substitution) factors.

Thermodynamic factors affecting this step include the acid-base equilibrium between reagents, release of solvent upon complexation, and product crystallization, which acts to drive the reaction forward. The water exchange in the metal coordination sphere, which leads to the complexes formation, is also governed by thermodynamic and kinetic (rate of substitution) factors.

elements.content: The method B, in which base is used for pH control, leads to the formation of higher dimensionality products, wherein the aprotic solvent (DMSO) does not act as a ligand. In this case, the addition of base modified the acid–base equilibrium established for the metalation and affected on the hydrolysis (reducing the water exchange rate). When the hydrolysis is faster than substitution, the metal shows a slow rate of substitution, and thus the DMSO molecule will not coordinate to the metal.

elements.content: In method A, the base is not used, and thus the kinetic of the reaction was not affected. Since the product was not controlled by kinetics, it can be said that, under the selected conditions, the compounds 1–4 were the thermodynamically stable products.

elements.content: The results presented above showed that the synthetic method plays a crucial role in the formation of coordination polymers since the same starter reactants provide distinct products. Comparing both synthetic methods, the products 1–4 are thermodynamic favored species, while the products 5–8 are kinetics favored species.

elements.content: The purity of the crystalline phase of each of the synthesized compounds was confirmed by the comparison between the experimental PXRD patterns and the ones calculated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The experimental PXRD patterns obtained for (6) indicated the formation of a new coordination polymer, since they match no calculated pattern obtained from the metal-fumarate CPs found in the CSD.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of the novel CPs (1–4) is presented in the Supporting Information (Section S2 and Figure S2). In order to investigate the solid state reactions for the new CPs obtained here, PXRD patterns were performed after heating up the samples ex situ (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Grinded samples of (2) and (4) were heated to and kept at 250 °C for 60 min. For (2), this heating led to mass loss due to complete releasing of DMSO and water molecules (Figure S2, Supporting Information) and also to the formation of the solid state phase identified as [Zn­(fum)], which is a 3D CP (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Therefore, the growth of 1D CPs crystals using the diffusion method followed by controlled heating is proposed as an alternate route to obtain more complex CPs with porous 3D structures. The procedure performed similar to (4) also led to a solid state phase transition (Figures S2 and S3, Supporting Information). However, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reported anhydrous structures of Zn2+ (or Co2+) and dhbdc with a PXRD pattern similar to that obtained after heating (4).
elements.clean_text:
Increasing the CPs Dimensionality

Thermogravimetric analysis of the novel CPs (1-4) is presented in the Supporting Information (Section S2 and Figure S2). In order to investigate the solid state reactions for the new CPs obtained here, PXRD patterns were performed after heating up the samples ex situ (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Grinded samples of (2) and (4) were heated to and kept at 250 °C for 60 min. For (2), this heating led to mass loss due to complete releasing of DMSO and water molecules (Figure S2, Supporting Information) and also to the formation of the solid state phase identified as [Zn(fum)], which is a 3D CP (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Therefore, the growth of 1D CPs crystals using the diffusion method followed by controlled heating is proposed as an alternate route to obtain more complex CPs with porous 3D structures. The  procedure performed similar to (4) also led to a solid state phase transition (Figures S2 and S3, Supporting Information). However, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reported anhydrous structures of Zn2+ (or Co2+) and dhbdc with a PXRD pattern similar to that obtained after heating (4).

elements.content: The crystal structures probed in this work for (1–4) confirm the formation of 1D CPs (linear chains) with general formula [trans-M­(dmso)2­(H2O)2(L)] n , where L = fum 2– (1 and 2) and dhbdc 2– (3 and 4) and M = Co2+ (1 and 3) and Zn2+ (2 and 4) (). All of their asymmetric units are comprised of one M2+ cation, one DMSO molecule, one water molecule, and half of a ligand molecule. All structures have the M2+ cations located at the inversion center, and this symmetry operation, when applied to the remaining atoms in the asymmetric unit, generates the octahedral geometry formed by two H2O, two DMSO molecules, and two ligands around the metals ().
elements.clean_text:
(1-4) Crystal Structures Analysis

Molecular Structure and Isomorphism

The crystal structures probed in this work for (1-4) confirm the formation of 1D CPs (linear chains) with general formula [trans-M(dmso)2(H2O)2(L)] n , where L = fum 2-  (1 and 2) and dhbdc 2-  (3 and 4) and M = Co2+ (1 and 3) and Zn2+ (2 and 4) (). All of their asymmetric units are comprised of one M2+ cation, one DMSO molecule, one water molecule, and half of a ligand molecule. All structures have the M2+ cations located at the inversion center, and this symmetry operation, when applied to the remaining atoms in the asymmetric unit, generates the octahedral geometry formed by two H2O, two DMSO molecules, and two ligands around the metals ().

elements.content: The crystal structure pairs (1) and (2) (hereinafter called fum-pair) and (3) and (4) (hereinafter called dhbdc-pair) present the same chemical composition, except for the metal ion (Co2+ or Zn2+) and crystallize in the same space group (P21/n) with very similar unit cells and very similar atomic coordinates ( and ). Therefore, (1) can be called an isomorphous crystal of (2), and (3) is an isomorphous crystal of (4). Even though the term “‘very similar”’ has not been defined in quantitative terms, the unit cell dimensions of isomorphic crystals are expected to be slightly different as a consequence of different ionic, covalent, or metallic radii of the different atoms. However, for the two isomorphic pairs reported here, no tendency is observed () due to the high similarity of the six-coordinated octahedral ionic radii of Zn2+ (0.74 Å) and Co2+ (0.745 Å, high spin). The invariance in the unit cell of both fum-pair and dhbdc-pair was also confirmed by the superposition of their respective experimental and calculated PXRD patterns (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

elements.content: It is important to note that isomorphism is a recurring behavior for octahedral aqua-coordinate CPs of Zn2+ and Co2+ with either fum 2– or dhbdc 2– ligands, as shown in the following cases: (i) the 1D CPs (linear chain) with general formula [M­(H2O)4­(fum)] n , where M = Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+; (ii) the 1D CPs (zigzag chain) with general formula [M­(H2O)4­(fum)] n ­H2O n , where M = Zn2+, Co2+, and Mg2+; and (iii) the 3D CPs of fum 2– with Zn2+ and Co2+. Isomorphic crystals of 3D CPs of dhbdc 2– ligand with Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ cations have also been reported.

elements.content: Concerning the geometry of the molecules, the M–O distances are in the range of 2.0603(9)–2.1148(9)­Å for (1), 2.0490(15)–2.1330(17) Å for (2), 2.076(3)–2.132(3) Å for (3), and 2.0962(11)–2.1095(12) Å for (4), and the O–M–O angles for (1–4) are near 90° (Table S1, Supporting Information). The similarity in the M–O distances and O–M–O angles involving homologous atoms for (1–4) are due to (i) the isomorphism present in both, fum-pair and dhbdc-pair; (ii) the difference between the six-coordinated ionic radii of Co2+ (high spin) and Zn2+ being only 0.05 Å; and (iii) the similarity of the coordination spheres (both fum 2– (fum-pair) and dhbdc 2– (dhbdc-pair) anions work as μ2-type bridging ligand in a monodentate mode). The overlay of the molecular backbones of (1) and (3) (Co2+ homologous) in a capped stick fashion is shown in emphasizing the coordination sphere similarity. The metals and the six oxygen atoms coordinated to them were selected as a pair of homologous atoms.

elements.content: Several 1D CPs of Zn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Mg2+ bridged by μ2-fumarate in monodentate mode, with the octahedral environment completed by four water molecules, have been reported. These 1D CPs with general formula [M­(H2O)4­(fum)] n will be hereinafter termed as tetra-aqua analogues.
elements.clean_text:
Comparing fum-pair and Known Analogous Structures

Several 1D CPs of Zn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Mg2+ bridged by μ2-fumarate in monodentate mode, with the octahedral environment completed by four water molecules, have been reported. These 1D CPs with general formula [M(H2O)4(fum)] n  will be hereinafter termed as tetra-aqua analogues.

elements.content: The known tetra-aqua analogues have assembled chains with either linear or zigzag structures (). Linear chains are observed for tetra-aqua analogues when a pair of fum 2– ligands is trans-coordinated to each metal (hereinafter termed as trans-L-M-L coordination), and zigzag chains are observed when two neighbor fum 2‑ ligands are cis-coordinated to each metal (hereinafter termed as cis-L-M-L coordination). It is noted that the ligands form intrachain H bonds involving a pair of cis - (for linear chains) or trans-coordinated water molecules (for zigzag chains).

elements.content: Interestingly, for all tetra-aqua analogues, no matter whether they form linear or zigzag chains, a common structural feature is present: a non-coplanar cis-orientated S(6) graph sets around the metals (). As expected, the cis-orientated S(6) graph sets observed for linear 1D CPs requires cis-coordinated water molecules. On the other hand, a pair of trans-coordinated water molecules is mandatory for the zigzag chains. Consequently, the neighbor S(6) graph sets sharing the same fum 2– molecule are coplanar for zigzag chains and twisted for linear ones. Indeed, it seems that all linear tetra-aqua analogues require the opposite carboxylate moieties to be twisted relative to one another.

elements.content: Let us now take into account the 1D CPs with octahedral coordinated metals having all ligands coordinated in monodentate mode and having fum 2– as μ2-bridging ligand, two trans-coordinated water molecules, and a pair of a third ligand (different from water and fum 2– ) also trans-coordinated to the metal. Hereafter these CPs with the general formula [M­(L)2­(H2O)2­(fum)] n will be termed trans-diaqua analogues. This is the case of the fum-pair reported here, in which L is a DMSO molecule. It is important to mention that regardless of what L is in the trans-diaqua analogues, the concomitant trans-coordination mode of water and L precludes the formation of zigzag chains (). Hence, fum-pair and all known trans-diaqua analogues form linear chains with trans-L-M-L coordination mode. Accordingly, all of them present coplanar trans-orientated S(6) graph sets around the metals, therefore, more planar fum 2– ligands ().

elements.content: As mentioned above for the tetra-aqua analogues, the cis–trans coordination of the water molecules impacts on the fum 2– planarity. Indeed, this statement can be extended for the trans-diaqua analogues including the fum-pair. More planar fum 2– molecules are expected when the S(6) graph sets are formed by trans-coordinated water molecules. This situation does not only occur for the tetra-aqua analogues with linear chains, which have S(6) graph sets formed by cis-coordinated water molecules (see and ).

elements.content: The tetra-aqua and trans-diaqua analogues exhibit another very important difference. The latter shows linkage isomerism, whereas the former do not. Since fum 2– works as a monodentate μ2-bridging ligand in the compared structures, it can be considered as an ambidentate ligand, which can potentially give rise to linkage isomers. Note that the carboxylate oxygen atoms of fum 2– can be differentiated in terms of the relative orientation of CO (or C–O−) and C–H bonds (). There are two CO bonds cis to the closest C–H bond considering the same fum 2– carboxylate side and two other trans to the same bond. In this way, fum 2– can bridge metals through three different combinations of pairs of opposite carboxylate oxygen atoms: M–O cis –fum–O trans –M, or M–O cis –fum–O cis –M, or M–O trans –fum–O trans –M linkage (a). Besides the cis-trans isomerism, which depends on the coordination position of the fum 2– ligand, the tetra-aqua and trans-diaqua analogues can also present linkage isomerism. As matter of fact, all 1D CPs bridged by μ2-fumarates can show linkage isomerism. It is important to note that these opposite oxygen atoms present different separations: O trans –fum–O trans < O cis –fum–O cis . Therefore, the metal–metal separation in chains with μ2-coordenation in M–O trans –fum–Otrans–M linkage mode is expected to be smaller than the M–O cis –fum–O cis –M one (b), as will be discussed later.

elements.content: Interestingly, for the known tetra-aqua analogues, only structures with M–O cis –fum–O cis –M linkage are observed (see and ). The M–O cis –fum–O cis –M linkage using the longest diametrical fum 2– oxygen atoms appear to be required on the cis-orientated S(6) graph sets to enable the intrachain H bond involving water oxygen atoms that should be separated by ∼9.8 Å (see ).

elements.content: It is time now to discuss the impact of these differences in the metal–metal intrachain separations. For (1) and (2), these distances coincide with their respective b crystallographic axes (see ), which are 8.9892(4) and 8.9725(5) Å, respectively. Fum-pair possesses M–O trans –fum–O trans –M linkage and therefore their metal–metal distances are, as expected, very similar to the trans-diaqua analogues with M–O trans –fum–O trans –M linkage. On the other hand, they are ∼1 Å shorter than the tetra-aqua and trans-diaqua analogues with M–O cis –fum–Ocis–M linkage. Chains with M–O trans –fum–O trans –M (structure (1) reported here) and M–O trans –fum–O trans –M (CCDC code: IKIBUZ) linkages are superimposed in c to illustrate these differences. Since the separation of O trans –O trans diametrical carboxylate oxygen atoms are ∼1 Å shorter than O cis –O cis ones, the intrachain metal–metal separations with M–O trans –fum–Otrans–M or M–Ocis–fum–Ocis–M linkage follow this difference (). Moreover, shows that there is a linear correlation of the distances of coordinated diametrical carboxylate oxygen atoms with intrachain metal–metal separations. Strikingly, the curve also suggests that it is possible to discriminate tetra-aqua 1D CPs with linear and zigzag structures.

elements.content: Summarizing, it is observed that the trans-diaqua analogues form only linear chains (trans-L-M-L coordinated and trans-orientated S(6) graph sets), but can show either M–O cis –fum–O cis –M or M–O trans –fum–O trans –M linkage. On the other hand, tetra-aqua analogues can form either linear (trans-L-M-L coordination and cis-coordinated water molecules) or zigzag chains (cis-L-M-L coordination and trans-coordinated water molecules) but only show cis-orientated S(6) graph sets and M–O cis –fum–O cis –M linkage.

elements.content: Indeed, all geometric differences are associated with multiple cis–trans isomerism: (i) cis–trans position of the water molecule participating in the S(6) graph sets around the metal, (ii) cis–trans geometry in the S(6) graph sets, (iii) cis–trans coordination of fum 2– to the metallic centers, (iv) linkage isomerism of fum 2– (M–O trans –fum–O trans –M or M–O cis –fum–O cis –M) to metals. Moreover, this multiple isomerism impacts (v) the intrachain metal–metal distances, (vi) the ligand planarity and (vii) chain type structures (linear or zigzag).

elements.content: Differently from fum-pair, there is no reported aqua-octahedral structure that is comparable to dhbdc-pair. Indeed, (3) and (4) are the first structural reports of octahedral aqua-dhbdc CPs with 1D structure (chains) having dhbdc exhibiting a monodentate coordination mode. The known structures of aqua-dobdc analogues are all 3D CPs, in which dobdc (2,5-dioxyterephtalic acid) works as a polyfunctional ligand (chelating and/or monatomic bridging and/or syn, syn- and/or syn, anti- and/or anti, anti- and/or syn, anti, anti and/or syn, syn, anti) leading to μ4 or μ8 bridging coordination (), e.g., M-MOF-74. Actually, the formation of 1D CPs of dhbdc appears to be correlated to the monodentante coordination mode exhibited by this ligand, and examples of such structures are scarce in the literature. One of the few examples and maybe the only one for which the structure was determined is the tetrahedral coordinated zigzag 1D CP catena-[(μ2-2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-benzenedicarboxylato-O,O′)-diaqua-zinc­(II)]. In (3), the monodentate coordination of the dhbdc-pair occurs through the carboxylate oxygen atoms that are non-hydrogen bonded to the dhbdc aromatic hydroxyl group (). Furthermore, the aromatic hydroxyl groups of dhbdc-pair remain protonated. The carboxyl and the aromatic moieties of the dhbdc 2– anion of the dhbdc-pair are coplanar. Considering the non-H atoms, the largest deviation from the least-squares plane computed for the dhbdc 2– atoms is 0.0091 Å for (3) and 0.0101 Å for (4). This is an expected geometric feature considering the intramolecular H bond involving O3 and O2. A very planar dobdc 2– is also observed for the 3D CP of Mn2+, for which the aromatic hydroxyl group is also protonated, enabling the intramolecular H-bond as in the dhbdc-pair.

Comparing dhbdc-pair and Known Analogous Structures

The known structures of aqua-dobdc analogues are all 3D CPs, in which dobdc (2,5-dioxyterephtalic acid) works as a polyfunctional ligand (chelating and/or monatomic bridging and/or syn, syn- and/or syn, anti- and/or anti, anti- and/or syn, anti, anti and/or syn, syn, anti) leading to μ4 or μ8 bridging coordination (), e.g., M-MOF-74. Actually, the formation of 1D CPs of dhbdc appears to be correlated to the monodentante coordination mode exhibited by this ligand, and examples of such structures are scarce in the literature. One of the few examples and maybe the only one for which the structure was determined is the tetrahedral coordinated zigzag 1D CP catena-[(μ2-2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-benzenedicarboxylato-O,O')-diaqua-zinc(II)]. In (3), the monodentate coordination of the dhbdc-pair occurs through the carboxylate oxygen atoms that are non-hydrogen bonded to the dhbdc aromatic hydroxyl group (). This is an expected geometric feature considering the intramolecular H bond involving O3 and O2. A very planar dobdc 2-  is also observed for the 3D CP of Mn2+, for which the aromatic hydroxyl group is also protonated, enabling the intramolecular H-bond as in the dhbdc-pair.

elements.content: For the CPs in which the aromatic hydroxyl groups are deprotonated, a significant deviation of the dhbdc 2– carboxyl oxygen atoms pertaining to the ligand aromatic moiety from the least-squares plane is observed. The noncoplanarity can be attributed to the absence of the intramolecular H-bond whose formation is due to the deprotonation of the aromatic hydroxyl group. The latter results in several dhbdc coordination modes, such as chelating, monatomic bridging, etc.

elements.content: In fum-pair structures, all chains grow parallel to their unit cell [010] direction, whereas for the dhbdc-pair ones, the chains grow parallel to their unit cell [110] or [1̅10] directions (). Parallel fum-pair chains along the [110] direction are linked by intermolecular H-bonds, forming a 2D supramolecular network (layer) parallel to the (101) plane (). It is observed that the uncoordinated O2 atom ( and ) works as a bifurcated H-bond acceptor for the H atoms linked to the two water molecules related by symmetry. The strong intramolecular H-bond involving H8 atom generates an S(6) graph set, whereas the intermolecular one formed by H9 atom links neighbor chains generating, along with O2···H8–O3, other two graph sets (C 2 2(11) and R 2 2(15) (). The stacking of the layers is stabilized by interchain weak H-bonds. They are formed by interchain DMSO molecules and fum 2− O1 and O4 atoms (C3–H4···O4, C4–H6···O4, and C3–H3···O1), resulting in a dimeric DMSO cage (). The fum-pair layers are stacked along the [101] direction and separated by 6.855 and 6.904 Å for (1) and (2), respectively (). Analyzing the intralayer features, the distance between intralayer chains are found to be 5.920 Å for (1) and 5.921 Å for (2), and the shortest intralayer neighbor-chain metal–metal separations for (1) and (2) are exactly equal to half of the length of the respective unit cell diagonal along [111]: 7.433(3) Å for (1) and 7.429(4) Å for (2) (). The corresponding values for the tetra-aqua analogues of Co2+ and Zn2+ are 7.346 and 7.305 Å, respectively, which are similar to the observed distances in (1) and (2).
elements.clean_text:
Fum-pair and dhbdc-pair Chain Packings

In fum-pair structures, all chains grow parallel to their unit cell [010] direction, whereas for the dhbdc-pair ones, the chains grow parallel to their unit cell [110] or [1̅10] directions (). Parallel fum-pair chains along the [110] direction are linked by intermolecular H-bonds, forming a 2D supramolecular network (layer) parallel to the (101) plane (). It is observed that the uncoordinated O2 atom ( and ) works as a bifurcated H-bond acceptor for the H atoms linked to the two water molecules related by symmetry. The strong intramolecular H-bond involving H8 atom generates an S(6) graph set, whereas the intermolecular one formed by H9 atom links neighbor chains generating, along with O2⋅⋅⋅H8-O3, other two graph sets (C 2 2(11) and R 2 2(15) (). The stacking of the layers is stabilized by interchain weak H-bonds. They are formed by interchain DMSO molecules and fum 2- O1 and O4 atoms (C3-H4⋅⋅⋅O4, C4-H6⋅⋅⋅O4, and C3-H3⋅⋅⋅O1), resulting in a dimeric DMSO cage (). The fum-pair layers are stacked along the [101] direction and separated by 6.855 and 6.904 Å for (1) and (2), respectively (). Analyzing the intralayer features, the distance between intralayer chains are found to be 5.920 Å for (1) and 5.921 Å for (2), and the shortest intralayer neighbor-chain metal-metal separations for (1) and (2) are exactly equal to half of the length of the respective unit cell diagonal along [111]: 7.433(3) Å for (1) and 7.429(4) Å for (2) (). The corresponding values for the tetra-aqua analogues of Co2+ and Zn2+ are 7.346 and 7.305 Å, respectively, which are similar to the observed distances in (1) and (2).

elements.content: Now, discussing the interlayer features, the shortest interlayer metal–metal separations for (1) and (2) are their respective a crystallographic axes: Co2+ = 7.7340(4) Å and Zn2+ = 7.7905(4) Å. These values are bigger than those reported for the tetra-aqua analogues (Co2+ = 5.011 Å and Zn2+ = 5.014 Å, Figure S4, Supporting Information). This is a consequence of higher hindrance effects of DMSO molecules when compared to water molecules to fill the interlayer cavities (e.g, the interlayer separation is 6.855 Å for (1) and 2.913 Å for the tetra-aqua analogue of Co2+. and Figure S4, Supporting Information).

elements.content: For dhbdc-pair, the O2 atom also acts as a bifurcated H-bond acceptor, but having the two H-bond donors from the same chain: one H atom from the water molecule and another from the hydroxyl group of dhbdc. The two intramolecular H-bonds involving O2 form two neighbor S(6) graph sets. The intermolecular H bond network of the dhbdc-pair involves the system O4–H10···O1, generating C 1 1(4) and R 2 2(8) graph sets, as shown in . Differently from fum-pair, for which O1 does not participate in the H-bonds, both carboxylate oxygen atoms contribute to the stabilization of the dhbdc-pair packing, acting as H bond acceptors.

elements.content:
Relevant structural difference is also observed when comparing the chain and layers formed by the fum-pair and the dhbdc-pair.

For the fum-pair, besides the coplanarity of the intrachain metal cations and fum 2– ligands, discussed above (a), it is also observed that the least-squares plane through the colayer metals are very close to the plane through the colayer fum 2– ligands (). On the other hand, the dhbdc-pair chain directions do not lay in the least-squares plane through dhbdc 2– atoms (). It is observed that the least-squares planes through neighbor dhbdc 2– ligands generate a stair-fashioned chain, with steps of ∼1.2 Å, and it is also noted that the chain direction makes an angle of ∼6° with the steps. Moreover, for the dhbdc-pair, the least-squares plane through the colayer metals makes an angle of ∼42° with the plane through the chain (considering the intrachain metals, water oxygen atoms, and non-hydrogen dhbdc 2– atoms) (). This noncoplanarity results in a shortening of the distance between chains in the same layer (see distances depicted in ). These values are above 1 Å, thus larger than those observed for the fum-pair (see distances depicted in ).

elements.content: Coordination polymers of Co2+ and Zn2+ with fumaric acid (fum) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephtalic acid (dhbdc) were synthesized employing two different synthetic methods: the liquid–liquid solvent diffusion (Method A) and pH control method (Method B), in which the same solvents, stoichiometry, and counterion were used. The use of base for pH control in method B increases the hydrolysis; when the hydrolysis is faster than substitution, the water exchange rate of Co2+ and Zn2+ is reduced, leading to compounds with more water molecules present in the coordination sphere of the metals, yielding products with higher dimensionality and complexity. Thus, compounds 5–8 are considered kinetic products. On the other hand, in Method A the water exchange rate is not affected, leading to thermodynamically more stable products, in which the aprotic solvent (DMSO) replaces the water in the inner coordination sphere of the metals. Thus, compounds 1–4 are considered thermodynamic products. Therefore, the products obtained under diffusion conditions present reduced dimensionality, since DMSO is not a potential donor/acceptor hydrogen bonding molecule. The method A led to four new coordination polymers with fum and dhbdc, in which two water molecules, two DMSO molecules, and two ligands (as μ2-bridging) coordinated the metal (Co and Zn). Besides providing isostructural compounds, this synthesis led to the formation of two pairs of isomorphous crystals ((1) and (2), and (3) and (4)). Hence, our results using diffusion crystal growth procedures to obtain crystals of Zn2+ and Co2+ with fum 2– or dhbdc 2– in water/DMSO medium confirm the tendency of these metal–ligand combinations to form isomorphous crystals. It can be concluded here that compounds with the general formula [M­(L)2(H2O)2­(fum)] n as (1) and (2), called trans-diaqua analogues of fum, can form only linear chains (trans-L-M-L coordinated and trans-orientated S(6) graph sets). Moreover, the M–O trans –fum–O trans –M linkage isomerism observed in (1) and (2) results in smaller intrachain metal–metal distances when compared to trans-diaqua analogues with M–O cis –fum–O cis –M linkage. It was also emphasized that compounds with the general formula [M­(H2O)4­(fum)] n , called tetra-aqua analogues, can form either linear or zigzag chains, but only show M–O cis –fum–O cis –M linkage. Thus, there is linear correlation between the coordination of fum oxygen (O cis –fum–O cis or O trans –fum–O trans ) and the intrachain metal–metal distances. Conclusively, correlated structural changes can be tuned by varying the number of water molecules (diaqua or tetra-aqua) coordinated to the CPs containing μ2-fumarate. This is allowed by the usage of different synthetic methods and/or crystal growth techniques as it was shown here (Method A and B). The final important conclusion is that the new series of 1D CPs obtained by diffusion method can be transformed into more complex CPs with 3D porous structures by thermal procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Coordination polymers of Co2+ and Zn2+ with fumaric acid (fum) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephtalic acid (dhbdc) were synthesized employing two different synthetic methods: the liquid-liquid solvent diffusion (Method A) and pH control method (Method B), in which the same solvents, stoichiometry, and counterion were used. The use of base for pH control in method B increases the hydrolysis; when the hydrolysis is faster than substitution, the water exchange rate of Co2+ and Zn2+ is reduced, leading to compounds with more water molecules present in the coordination sphere of the metals, yielding products with higher dimensionality and complexity. Thus, compounds 5-8 are considered kinetic products. On the other hand, in Method A the water exchange rate is not affected, leading to thermodynamically more stable products, in which the aprotic solvent (DMSO) replaces the water in the inner coordination sphere of the metals. Thus, compounds 1-4 are considered thermodynamic products. Therefore, the products obtained under diffusion conditions present reduced dimensionality, since DMSO is not a potential donor/acceptor hydrogen bonding molecule. The method A led to four new coordination polymers with fum and dhbdc, in which two water molecules, two DMSO molecules, and two ligands (as μ2-bridging) coordinated the metal (Co and Zn). Besides providing isostructural compounds, this synthesis led to the formation of two pairs of isomorphous crystals ((1) and (2), and (3) and (4)). Hence, our results using diffusion crystal growth procedures to obtain crystals of Zn2+ and Co2+ with fum 2-  or dhbdc 2-  in water/DMSO medium confirm the tendency of these metal-ligand combinations to form isomorphous crystals. It can be concluded here that compounds with the general formula [M(L)2(H2O)2(fum)] n  as (1) and (2), called trans-diaqua analogues of fum, can form only linear chains (trans-L-M-L coordinated and trans-orientated S(6) graph sets). Moreover, the M-O trans -fum-O trans -M linkage isomerism observed in (1) and (2) results in smaller intrachain metal-metal distances when compared to trans-diaqua analogues with M-O cis -fum-O cis -M linkage. It was also emphasized that compounds with the general formula [M(H2O)4(fum)] n , called tetra-aqua analogues, can form either linear or zigzag chains, but only show M-O cis -fum-O cis -M linkage. Thus, there is linear correlation between the coordination of fum oxygen (O cis -fum-O cis  or O trans -fum-O trans ) and the intrachain metal-metal distances. Conclusively, correlated structural changes can be tuned by varying the number of water molecules (diaqua or tetra-aqua) coordinated to the CPs containing μ2-fumarate. This is allowed by the usage of different synthetic methods and/or crystal growth techniques as it was shown here (Method A and B). The final important conclusion is that the new series of 1D CPs obtained by diffusion method can be transformed into more complex CPs with 3D porous structures by thermal procedures.
